categories.name: Biversion
categories.description: Two separate parts in different languages and a content which is usually at least in part common to both

categories.name: Duplicating
categories.description: Same content in each version

categories.name: Partial
categories.description: Versions say partly the same thing, but one says more

categories.name: Overlapping
categories.description: Versions say different things, but part of it is the same in both

categories.name: Complementary
categories.description: Versions say different things, but part of the same text

categories.name: Bilingual Phenomena
categories.description: Composed in one language but showing bilingual phenomena from another

categories.name: Code Switching
categories.description: Full blown switch from one language into another

categories.name: Tag Switching
categories.description: Switch for e.g. a formula such as VSLM

categories.name: inter-sentential
categories.description: Between sentence/clause boundaries

categories.name: Intra Sentential
categories.description: Within sentence/clause boundaries

categories.name: Morphological
categories.example: e.g. the ‘Greek Latin’ deployed in the res gestae or senatus consulta etc.?

categories.name: Phonetic
categories.example: e.g. Lusitanian word endings in Latin texts

categories.name: Interference
categories.description: Features from another language unintentionally transferred into the main language of the text

categories.name: Borrowing
categories.description: Adoption of any linguistic element from one language into another. The items function in the adopting language as native elements, often with some degree of integration

categories.name: Calque
categories.description: Translation of a foreign expression by a new native form which matches the foreign, e.g. sky-scraper, gratte-ciel

categories.name: Loan Shifting
categories.description: When a word undergoes semantic extension on the model of a foreign counterpart

categories.name: Translingualism
categories.description: When forms chosen seem to be expressing more than one language at the same time, e.g. nata. This is a tricky one because sometimes it is simply the case that we cannot work out which language to assign something to, but in some cases it seems there is a desire to use translingualism (e.g. some of the Gaulish-Latin spindle whorls)

categories.name: Mixed Language
categories.description: In genetically mixed languages or codes that are so mixed that it is impossible to identify the dominant language.

categories.name: Translingual
categories.description: Different from Text with bilingual phenomena: translingualism, as the whole text would be translingual.

categories.name: biscriptal
categories.description: Same language but using two script systems

categories.name: Transliterated
categories.description: Whole text is in a script which is not the primary one used for that language.

categories.name: Biscriptal Phenomena
categories.description: e.g. Velleron stele is Gaulish in Greek script but with valete which is Latin written in Greek script, so that text could be tagged with Text with bilingual phenomena: Code-switching: intra-sentential: lexical AND Text with graphic phenomena: Transliteration

categories.name: Graphic Interference
categories.description: (‘accidental’) letter forms/orthographic rules from the script with which the author is more familiar intrude into the script of the text.

categories.name: Transliteration
categories.description: either by choice or because author doesn’t know the other script of another language being used e.g. for code-switching in the primary

categories.name: Graphic Borrowing
categories.description: when a script form is used from another set used to write a different language, for example to represent a sound in a name, e.g. tau gallicum forms in Gaulish names in Latin texts.
